concept_definition: Coming before all others in order; number one in a sequence.
notes: This entry treats 'first' as the ordinal adjective (base/positive form). 'First' can also function as an adverb (e.g., 'First, ...') or a noun (e.g., 'the first'), and translations may change by grammatical role. Lithuanian adverbial equivalent: 'pirmiausia'. Chinese adverbial equivalent: '首先'. Korean adverbial equivalent: '먼저'. French adverbial equivalent: 'd'abord'. Swahili adverbial equivalent: 'kwanza'. Vietnamese adverbial equivalents: 'đầu tiên', 'trước hết'. Depending on language grammar (gender, definiteness, noun-class agreement), exact surface forms may vary.

concept_definition: An ordinal adjective meaning 'coming after the first in a series; number two in order'. Used to indicate position (e.g., the second item).
notes: This entry focuses on the ordinal meaning (Lithuanian 'antras'). In Lithuanian the adjective must agree in gender, number and case (e.g., antras [masc. nom. sg.], antra [fem. nom. sg.]). Do not confuse this sense with other meanings of English 'second' such as the time unit 'second' (Lithuanian: 'sekundė') or 'to second' (to support a motion), which have different translations.

concept_definition: The ordinal indicating position number three in an ordered sequence (after second and before fourth). Used to describe the item that comes in position three.
notes: Primary sense analyzed is the ordinal adjective (positive form) corresponding to Lithuanian 'trečias'. In English 'third' can also be used nominally (e.g., 'He finished third') or represented numerically as '3rd'. In Lithuanian adjectives agree in gender, number and case (e.g., trečias (m. sg.), trečia (f. sg.), trečia (n. sg. in some contexts), trečių (gen. pl.), etc.). In Swahili ordinal forms depend on noun class (common, for people often 'wa tatu'); many contexts may use the cardinal 'tatu' with an ordinal particle.

concept_definition: Denoting the position number four in an ordered sequence; the ordinal corresponding to the number four.
notes: Primary meaning treated here is the ordinal adjective (as in "the fourth item") corresponding to Lithuanian 'ketvirtas'. In English 'fourth' can also function nominally ("the fourth" = "the fourth one"). Lithuanian equivalents will be inflected for gender and case (e.g., ketvirta for feminine nominative). Numeric abbreviations (4th, 4-as) are commonly used in both languages.

concept_definition: The ordinal number equal to five; used to indicate something in position number five in an ordered sequence.
notes: Primary use: ordinal adjective (e.g., "the fifth person"). English 'fifth' can also be used as a noun ("the fifth in line") and in specialized senses (musical 'fifth' interval). Translations are given in base/lemma forms: Chinese uses the particle 第 + cardinal (第五); Korean commonly appears as 다섯째 or 다섯 번째; French shorthand can be written 5e. Lithuanian adjectives inflect for gender, number and case (penktas - masculine nominative singular; penktasis is the definite form). Swahili forms ordinals with noun-class prefixes (e.g., 'wa tano' or 'ya tano' depending on noun class); 'tano' is given as the base numeral. Vietnamese ordinal marker is 'thứ' + cardinal (thứ năm).

concept_definition: Being number six in a series or order; the position after fifth and before seventh.
notes: Primary use: ordinal adjective (e.g., "the sixth item"). Can also be used as a noun in English ("the sixth"). Translations depend on grammatical agreement: Lithuanian ordinals inflect for gender/case (base masculine form given: "šeštas"); Chinese uses the ordinal prefix 第 + numeral ("第六"); Korean commonly uses "여섯 번째" (or "여섯째"); French ordinal abbreviation is "6e"; Swahili ordinals agree with noun class ("wa sita" is common for class of people/things requiring 'wa-'); Vietnamese ordinal form is "thứ sáu". Abbreviated numeric forms (6th, 6., 6e, 6-as) are common in various languages/writing systems.

concept_definition: The ordinal indicating position number seven in a sequence; coming after the sixth.
notes: Primary use: ordinal number (adjective); can also be used as a noun in contexts like "the seventh (one)". Lithuanian ordinals agree for gender and case — the provided Lithuanian lemma is the masculine nominative form ('septintas'); feminine and other forms include 'septintoji' etc. Chinese commonly appears as '第七' and may take a measure word (e.g., '第七个') for counted items. Korean alternatives include '일곱번째'. Swahili ordinals often use class prefixes (common form 'wa saba'). French and Vietnamese forms given are standard base forms. Abbreviated numeral forms (e.g., '7th', '7.', '第7', '7º') are common cross-linguistically.

concept_definition: An ordinal number meaning 'number eight in a sequence' or 'in the eighth position'. (Used to indicate order: 1st, 2nd, 3rd, ... 8th.)
notes: Primary use is as an ordinal numeral (adjective or determinative: the eighth item). In English it can sometimes be used as a noun to mean 'one of eight equal parts' but the distinct fraction form is usually 'one eighth' (or 'an eighth'). Lithuanian ordinals inflect for gender and definiteness (e.g., aštuntas, aštunta, aštuntasis). Swahili ordinals vary by noun class (forms like 'wa nane' or class-specific prefixes); Chinese and French commonly use compact numeric forms (第八, huitième) and short numeric abbreviations (第8, 8e).

concept_definition: An ordinal adjective meaning in position number nine in a sequence (one after eighth and before tenth).
notes: Primary use is as an ordinal adjective. It can also be used as a noun or pronoun (e.g., “the ninth” meaning the ninth person/thing). Lithuanian adjectives inflect for gender, number and case (dictionary lemma given is masculine nominative singular). Chinese and Korean ordinals are typically formed with a marker (第 in Chinese, 번째/째 or 제 in Korean). Swahili uses distinct ordinal forms (tisa for ninth).

concept_definition: The ordinal form of the number ten; indicates the position number ten in an ordered sequence (e.g., the tenth item).
notes: Primary analysis treats 'tenth' as an ordinal numeral (position 10). 'Tenth' can also be used as a noun meaning the fraction 'one tenth' (e.g., 'one tenth of a cake'); common translations for the fraction differ (Lithuanian: 'dešimtadalis' or 'dešimtoji dalis'; Chinese: '十分之一'). Lithuanian ordinals have gender and case (base/lemma here given as masculine nominative 'dešimtas'); alternates include 'dešimtasis'. Korean ordinal is commonly written '열 번째' or '열번째'. Swahili ordinal formation typically uses the prefix 'wa' plus the cardinal (here given as 'wa kumi').

concept_definition: coming after all others in time or order
